awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Fuel of Interest and Fire of Genius: Essays on the Timing, Direction, and Location of Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
Many argue that the promotion of innovation is one of the main social benefits of institutions of higher education. Relatively little is known, however, about the historic role of colleges in driving invention. This project creates unique data based on digitizing college yearbooks from the 1870s to the 1940s. The names of students from college yearbooks are matched to patent data, creating a picture of the role of colleges in promoting American ingenuity. These data show, for the first time, what share of patents come from college graduates and faculty. The yearbooks are also matched to historical censuses, answering questions about the mobility of college students. The yearbook data paints the clearest picture yet available of college participation by different demographic groups across time; the data reveal not only college attendance by women and African Americans, but also the college majors for these individuals, the sports and clubs in which they participate, and how their college experiences affect future labor market outcomes.

Important questions regarding the impact of colleges cannot be adequately answered without the kind of detailed student- and faculty-level data created in the project. Most notably, the college yearbook data solves three major problems. First, it allows for the estimation of knowledge spillovers from colleges by linking new inventions to faculty and graduates and distinguishing them from individuals who have had only indirect interactions with a particular college. Second, since the historical yearbooks give student names and identifying information, it is possible to track graduates across time and space rather than assuming they remain co-located with their alma maters. Third, the college yearbooks include information on students? majors, fraternity and sorority membership, and club and sports participation, allowing for estimation of the returns to education by major over a time period for which data has traditionally been very sparse, as well as an examination of how social networks forged in college affect later labor market outcomes

por.por_cntn:
How do colleges and universities affect the economy? This question is particularly important given recent debates over public funding of higher education. To study this question, researchers typically need individual-level data on college attendees. While this data is available in some cases for recent years, none exist for other time periods in U.S. history. This makes it difficult to assess the role of higher education, since one cannot compare outcomes today to higher education in the American past. Without historical data, key context is missing.

To fill this gap in knowledge, the researchers compile and transcribe a large dataset of historical college yearbooks. Once collected, data on college students and faculty can be matched to other datasets to learn how colleges affect various outcomes of interest. The yearbooks contain rich information about college seniors, graduate students, and faculty members. For the students, for example, the yearbooks include information on college majors, hometowns, sports, clubs, and activities, etc.

One challenge with creating this yearbook dataset is that the exact type of information included varies slightly across yearbooks, and formatting can change substantially even across pages within the same yearbook. This makes automated transcription methods such as optical character recognition (OCR) unsuitable for this project. Consequently, the yearbooks had to be manually transcribed. In total, the transcription process resulted in 43,912 college senior records, 2,254 graduate student records, and 13,201 faculty records from 198 college yearbooks from 20 different colleges and spanning the years 1893 to 1940.

The researchers use the newly-constructed yearbook dataset to match the names of college alumni and faculty to the names of inventors listed on U.S. patents. The goal of this specific project is to study the role of colleges and universities in promoting local invention. Creation of innovation clusters is a key policy goal, and a prominent college or university is often seen as a necessary condition to establishing an effective cluster. The researchers compare invention in places that receive a college to “runner-up” sites that were strongly considered to receive the college but were ultimately not selected. It appears that colleges do indeed help to create a local innovation hub: places that receive a new college have about 43% more patents per year than the runner-up locations. The yearbook data are then used to study who these additional 43% of patents are coming from. Surprisingly, the alumni of a particular college account for only about 3% of the additional patents in the college’s county. Faculty also account for a very small share of the additional patents in the college county, roughly 1%. The primary way by which higher education increases local patenting is through migration, by attracting people to come and live close to the college.

These findings challenge common conceptions about the role of universities: colleges play a local role primarily by encouraging migration and creating agglomeration economies, but many other policies could be equally as effective at attracting migrants. The researchers show that, at least from 1850 to 1940, the creation of other types of institutions, such as prisons or asylums, both attract migrants and increase patenting very similarly to the creation of a new college. Thus, colleges do not appear to be a necessary condition to create an innovation hub.

This study documents only one way through which colleges can affect the economy, namely by creating a local innovation hub. Of course, colleges can have many other effects. The yearbook data can shed light on these other effects as well. In ongoing work, the researchers and coauthors are using U.S. decennial census data to track the college alumni across time and space to answer questions such as:

-Are college alumni more likely to migrate to urban areas than non-graduates?

-Assuming college alumni move after graduation, are they more likely to patent in their new locations?

-What are the financial returns to education by college major, race, and gender during a period of time when this data is typically unavailable?

By creating a novel dataset, this study has produced a resource that can be used by other researchers to study many additional questions related to the role of higher education in the U.S. past.

Modified by: Michael Andrews
